conversation.content: Maria called me this morning. She saw him at the casino. [confused] My client, the one with the bakery proposal? [pause] Three thousand dollars for commercial ovens, that's what he wrote. Equipment financing. I have his business plan right here, profit projections, everything. [bitter] God, I actually defended him to the review committee. [sigh] They had concerns about his credit history and I said—I said people deserve second chances, you know? That microfinance is about, um... about believing in people who traditional banks won't touch. [angry] But gambling? Really? [frustrated] That money was supposed to help his family, supposed to create jobs in his neighborhood. [slowly] And now I have to report this. [regretful] I mean, obviously I have to report it. [pause] The thing is, I've seen what happens to these families when the loans default. His kids, his wife—they don't even know yet, do they? [very sad] Twenty-three years I've been doing this work. [quietly] Twenty-three years of believing that if you just give people a chance, they'll... [trailing off] [sigh] I guess I'm the one who gambled, really. Gambled on trust. And er... apparently I lost too.

subject: Your microlending client used the business loan for gambling instead of their stated purpose
